article_title: Flu season gives supermarkets a shot in the arm

article_metadata.description: I'm not getting medical care from the same place where I buy Gulden's Spicy Brown Mustard, paper towels and dog food.  [...] it was.  Eighteen years ago, I stood in line at a Mexican farmacia in Nuevo Laredo to buy discount hypodermic needles and syringes pre-filled with fertility drugs.  First he poked holes in my theory that Frank the produce manager gives flu shots at supermarkets.  In addition to my pharmacy degree, I was trained as an immunizer in 2003 through the American Pharmacy Association's Pharmacy Based Immunization Delivery Certificate Program.  The State Board of Pharmacy also requires me to do additional CE specific to immunizations every time I renew my license, be current in CPR and do annual Blood Borne Pathogen training, he said.  Randalls charges $28 for a standard flu shot, but the fee is covered by most health insurance plans.  Under the Affordable Care Act, preventive health care services such as immunizations are required to be covered 100 percent.  Most insurance plans now allow pharmacies to bill for immunization services with zero or minimal cost to the patient, Posterick said.  If flu shots are covered by insurance, why would anybody get a flu shot at a supermarket instead of a doctor's office?  Certified immunizers give flu shots at all Randalls during regular pharmacy hours – 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. Saturday, and 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday.  Since 2003, Randalls has given nearly a million flu shots to Texans.
article_metadata.author.name: By Ken Hoffman
